channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: African Training Exercise Turns Urgent as Threats Grow
item.description: New ties between Boko Haram and the Islamic State have reinforced American and European concerns that have led to the training of African troops.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The Chadian army trained with American Special Forces during the annual Exercise Flintlock in the Sahara Desert.

item.title: With Misattributed Constable Masterpiece, a Rare Look Into the Imprecise World of Art Identification
item.description: A painting by John Constable, which sold in 2013 for about $5,200 at Christie’s, was put on the block at Sotheby’s in January and fetched $5.2 million, a demonstration of what an expert’s opinion can do.
item.dc:creator: LORNE MANLY
item.media:description: John Constable’s “Salisbury Cathedral From the Meadows” sold for 1,000 times as much after it was deemed authentic.

item.title: Back in Afghanistan, Modern Romeo and Juliet Face Grave Risks
item.description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali had faced criminal charges and death threats after eloping and fleeing their village in the high mountains of central Afghanistan last year.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohammad Ali resting while preparing soil for a potato crop near his family home outside the town of Bamian in Afghanistan. He carries a pistol for protection.

item.title: Executives Are Jailed in Chile Finance Scandal
item.description: Four executives of one of Chile’s largest financial groups, a tax auditor and a former government official were taken into custody in a case that has shaken the economic elite and the main opposition party.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Boko Haram Generates Uncertainty With Pledge of Allegience to Islamic State
item.description: In an unconfirmed online message Saturday, the Nigerian group appears to make a spiritually binding oath to follow ISIS’ authority. But the practical significance of the move was unclear.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Jihadists May Have Wrecked an Ancient Iraqi Site
item.description: Iraqi officials are investigating reports that the Islamic State destroyed Hatra, an archaeological site dating to the first century B.C., two days after confirming that it bulldozed an ancient Assyrian city.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A temple in Hatra, an archaeological site from the first century B.C. Nearby residents report that the Islamic State destroyed it.

item.title: Egypt Executes an Islamist Supporter of Ousted President
item.description: Egypt’s government carried out the death penalty against man convicted of murder during the political violence that followed the military takeover of the government in 2013, the Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Foreign Workers Missing After Militants Attack Libyan Oil Field
item.description: About 10 foreigners were missing after an attack on a Libyan oil field, and it is possible they had been taken hostage, the Czech Republic’s foreign minister said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: After Talks, Nuclear Deal on Iran Is Seen as Close
item.description: With an end-of-March deadline for drafting the outline of a potential agreement, Secretary of State John Kerry faces an array of challenges in completing an initial accord and defending it to Congress.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Move Over Mao: Beloved ‘Papa Xi’ Awes China
item.description: Not since Mao dominated the nation with his masterly blend of populism, fervor and fear has a Chinese leader commanded as much public awe as President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of President Xi Jinping of China hanging in a restaurant in Beijing.

item.title: Gunman Kills Five in Restaurant in Mali
item.description: A ranking security official said Saturday morning that two people had been arrested in connection with the attack, for which a group of extremists are said to have claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Police officers blocked the street near La Terrasse restaurant in Bamako, Mali, on Saturday, after five people were shot dead overnight there in a suspected terrorist attack.

item.title: 2 Suspects Are Detained in Killing of Kremlin Critic
item.description: The director of Russia’s Federal Security Service named two men as suspects in the brazen shooting of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov in Moscow on Feb. 27, but questions remained over who orchestrated the killing.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Brazil Bribery Inquiry Targets Top Politicians
item.description: The leaders of both houses of Congress are among those to be investigated, by order of the Supreme Federal Tribunal, the nation’s highest court.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Kosovars Who Fought for Land Are Now Eager to Leave
item.description: A disastrous economy, static politics and a newly created opening in the border with Serbia have enticed tens of thousands of Kosovars to leave their troubled land.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The windows of a government building were smashed by rioters in protests against the government in January.

item.title: Companies Turn Tables on Human Rights Lawyers
item.description: American companies accused of human rights abuses abroad are on the counterattack, seeking to bring down the lawyers who targeted them.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: BARRY MEIER
item.media:credit: Diego M. Radzinschi/The National Law Journal
item.media:description: Terrence Collingsworth is one of a band of lawyers who have targeted multinational corporations for mistreating workers abroad. Now they find themselves on the defensive.

item.title: U.S. Relied on Unarmed South Korean Officer to Protect Envoy
item.description: The assignment of a single unarmed South Korean police bodyguard to accompany Ambassador Mark W. Lippert on his movements in the country added to questions about security when he was attacked.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Officers took Kim Ki-jong, the suspect in the attack on the American ambassador, from a police station in Seoul to court on Friday. Mr. Kim was injured while being subdued at the scene.

item.title: Pakistan Honors Victims of School Massacre
item.description: Education officials in northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province have renamed more than a hundred schools after the children killed last year in a Taliban attack on an army-run public school in Peshawar.
item.category: Army Public School and Degree College (Peshawar, Pakistan)
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Iraqi Forces Said to Near ISIS-Held Tikrit
item.description: Iraq’s largest offensive against Islamic State militants came a step closer to the city of Tikrit on Friday, according to Iraqi state television.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Mexico: Bodies Found Atop Volcano
item.description: A rescue team has found two bodies in a glacier on Mexico’s tallest peak, a dormant volcano.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Nigeria: American Missionary Is Freed
item.description: An American missionary who was kidnapped in central Nigeria in February was released on Friday, according to a statement from her church, the Free Methodist Church.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
